image.altText: A man looks at stock prices through the window of the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market rises to its highest level in a month, while ASIC cancels the financial services licence of cryptocurrency firm FTX's local subsidiary. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises to four-week high, ASIC cancels crypto firm FTX's financial services licence

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The corporate regulator has cancelled the financial services licence of cryptocurrency firm FTX's local subsidiary, effective from July 14. Last November, the Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC) had suspended the license until May, taking back its permit to deal in derivative and foreign exchange contracts to retail and wholesale clients. Bahamas-headquartered FTX, once a rising star of the crypto industry with a $US32 billion valuation in January 2023 filed for US bankrupty protection in November, saying it was unable to completely repay customers who had deposited funds on its exchange. Its founder Sam Bankman-Fried is facing numerous criminal fraud charges in the US courts. The terms of the cancellation include provisions that until the end of July 12 next year, FTX Australia may provide limited financial services that relate to the termination of existing derivatives with clients, ASIC said. If you're wondering what's happening with Mr Bankman-Fried's trial, here's the latest:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIC cancels FTX Australia's financial services licence

featuredLink.title: 'A rush to judgement': FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried urges court to toss charges

children.content: The corporate regulator has cancelled the financial services licence of cryptocurrency firm FTX's local subsidiary, effective from July 14.
Last November, the Australian Securities
Investments Commission (ASIC) had suspended
the license until May, taking back its permit to deal in derivative and foreign exchange contracts to retail and wholesale clients.

Bahamas-headquartered FTX, once a rising star of the crypto industry with a $US32 billion valuation in January 2023 filed for US bankrupty protection in November, saying it was unable to completely repay customers who had deposited funds on its exchange.
Its founder Sam Bankman-Fried is facing numerous criminal fraud charges in the US courts.

The terms of the cancellation include provisions that until the end of July 12 next year, FTX Australia may provide limited financial services that relate to the termination of existing derivatives with clients, ASIC said.
If you're wondering what's happening with Mr Bankman-Fried's trial, here's the latest:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand's consumer inflation came in slightly above expectations in the June quarter, pushing out the market's expectations for when the central bank might start cutting the cash rate. Consumer prices rose 6% in the year to June (slower than the 6.7% annualised increase in the March quarter), Statistics New Zealand said in a statement on Wednesday. It's now below the three-decade high of 7.3% inflation seen in the June quarter of 2022. Measured another way, the consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.1% between the March and June quarters. This result was just above economists’ expectations in a Reuters poll for a 1% rise for the quarter and a 5.9% annual rise. Inflation is a significant challenge for the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) and it has responded by raising interest rates to 5.5% from a record low 0.25% in October 2021. While it has said it now believes that the rate increases are having the desired impact on dampening inflation, it expects rates to hold at a "restrictive level" for the foreseeable future. The main drivers of the annual inflation were food and housing prices, according to Statistics New Zealand. "With food prices up 12.3% annually, consumers may be buying cheaper alternative to keep their food bill lower," said Nicola Growden, the prices senior manager at Statistics New Zealand. "The price of building a new home has increased by more than a third in the three years from the June 2020 quarter."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand inflation higher than expected

children.content: New Zealand's consumer inflation came in slightly above expectations in the June quarter, pushing out the market's expectations for when the central bank might start cutting the cash rate.
Consumer prices rose 6% in the year to June
(slower than the 6.7% annualised increase in the March quarter), Statistics New Zealand said in a statement on Wednesday.
It's now below the three-decade high of 7.3% inflation seen in the June quarter of 2022.
Measured another way,
the consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.1% between the March and June quarters.
This result was just above economists’ expectations in a Reuters poll for a 1% rise for the quarter and a 5.9% annual rise.
Inflation is a significant challenge for the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) and it has responded by raising interest rates to 5.5% from a record low 0.25% in October 2021.
While it has said it now believes that the rate increases are having the desired impact on dampening inflation, it expects rates to hold at a "restrictive level" for the foreseeable future.
The main drivers of the annual inflation were food and housing prices, according to Statistics New Zealand.
"With food prices up 12.3% annually, consumers may be buying cheaper alternative to keep their food bill lower," said Nicola Growden, the prices senior manager at Statistics New Zealand.
"The price of building a new home has increased by more than a third in the three years from the June 2020 quarter."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market is off to a solid start, with the ASX 200 index up 0.7% by 10:50am AEST. Eight out of every 10 stocks are trading higher (ie. most of them). Most sectors have risen, with energy being the best performing sector thanks to gains from Ampol (+5.1%), Whitehaven Coal (+2.9%) and Coronado Global Resources (+4%). Ampol reported a 54% drop in first-half refining margins at its Lytton refinery in Queensland, impacted by a five-week long outage at the plant. Meanwhile, shares BrainChip jumped 9.5% after the AI firm the US Patents and Trademarks Office approved its patent for a "neuromorphic processor". On the flip side, shares of gold miner Northern Star Resources have plunged 5.8%. That's despite the company forecasting higher gold sales in the current financial year, and after it reported a 6% jump in its fourth-quarter sales.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coal and petrol stocks drive ASX higher

children.content: The local share market is off to a solid start, with the
ASX 200 index up 0.7%
by 10:50am AEST.
Eight out of every 10 stocks are trading higher (ie. most of them).
Most sectors have risen, with energy being the best performing sector thanks to gains from Ampol (+5.1%), Whitehaven Coal (+2.9%) and Coronado Global Resources (+4%).
Ampol reported a
54% drop
in first-half refining margins at its Lytton refinery in Queensland, impacted by a five-week long outage at the plant.
Meanwhile, shares
BrainChip
jumped 9.5% after the AI firm the US Patents and Trademarks Office approved its patent for a "neuromorphic processor".
On the flip side, shares of gold miner
Northern Star Resources
have plunged 5.8%.
That's despite the company forecasting higher gold sales in the current financial year, and after it reported a 6% jump in its fourth-quarter sales.
